 The only auto-generation I've found useful is the simple test-class
templ=
ate available in most IDEs, beyond that it would seem to both miss
the poin=
t of the analysis and learning inherent in creating a test and
leave you pr=
one to suffering at the hands of an overly literal
test-generation algorith=
m. I would be very interested to hear of
anything better, but I do find it =
difficult to imagine anything that
would be capable of replacing the value =
of even a poor set of
hand-written tests.

 If you just like the idea of to=
ols as rewarding toys, then I like
Jester (http://jester.sourceforge.net/),=
 although it isn't exactly
simple to integrate into a development environme=
nt.

 I think Kevin Klinemeier caught the more approachable issue, which is=

how to encourage a team to develop their own tests. In addition to his
adv=
ice I can only suggest that you:

 1. Ask them to create tests as part of n=
ormal development tasks.
 2. Give them time to create the tests (although y=
ou will eventually
find the tests save time, they will need more time up-fr=
ont).
 3. Support them in creating the tests and don't place great pressure=
 on
them over it, especially if the underlying development is pressurised
a=
lready.
 4. Evaluate tests together, perhaps have a group task where each p=
erson
creates a test for a class or method and then you compare and discuss=

(this is where jester can be quite valuable in exposing test
blind-spots).=

 5. Link bug-fixing to test creation -- assuming that you have a
bug-datab=
ase, this is an effective way of adding tests of value to
existing code.
 6=
. If you feel they won't react badly to it, consider writing seed
tests you=
rself.


 Although we're meant to be rational, technical people, this is on=
e of
the many issues that is more problematic on an emotional level than it=

is in any practical sense. Only you know your team and how they work and
i=
t could be that none of the above would be useful for you. I can't
claim to=
 have cracked the problem myself, but there's always hope. 

 Best of luck =
with it,
 

 Damian Sinclair
